properties.name: Atlanta Dragway
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick 500 E Ridgeway RD Commerce, GAYes, it\'s a dragway, no, it\'s not very close to Atlanta. It\'s not too far from Athens, and not terribly far from Gwinett County, but it\'s quite a haul from here to Downtown Atlanta and even farther for us west of town. Interesting that the NASCAR track down in Hampton isn\'t all that close to Atlanta either, but I suppose it\'s closer than Commerce. Well, here\'s where I get my racing fix. I can\'t stand to watch the round track drivers ride around in a circle 500 times. If that\'s your fancy, bonus, but I\'m sorry, I\'ve wasted all my patience for a long sporting event on the baseball game. Now when it comes to auto racing, I want it to be quick. By the time it takes round track to finish one race, the drag strip has hosted scores of races. The top fuel and funny cars here run in the low 4\'s. That\'s a quarter of a mile in just over 4 seconds for those who don\'t know. The power that these machines generate is nothing short of incredible. I saw a car with a jet engine at an air show at Dobbins AFB one time, and that thing looked slower than molasses compared to these cars. I\'m sure many of you have seen a Ferrari outrun a fighter jet for a quarter mile. That\'s what I\'m talking about. Sometimes I wonder, how much faster can they get? If the races end in less than 3 seconds at that level, will people start to complain that they\'re not getting their money\'s worth?

properties.name: Aunt Martha
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick 3196 Misty Valley Dr Macon, GAThis is where my Aunt lives in Macon. My grandmother used to live in Macon for several years, too.

properties.name: Battle of Dallas - Bishop's Bridge
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickDallas, GAOn May 26, 1864, Brigadier General Jefferson Columbus Davis (the Confederate President was named Jefferson Finis Davis), reached Dallas along the Dallas - Mount Olivet Road by crossing Pumpkinvine Creek near here on the old road at what was then called Bishop\'s Bridge. Brigadier General Davis\' 2nd Division of the 14th Army Corps broke away from Sherman\'s main force on May 19th and followed a route west of the Oostanaula River to attack Rome. On May 24, Brigadier General Jefferson Davis left Rome and marched south - southeast to Peek\'s Spring (now known as Aragon) and then to Van Wert. From Van Wert, as the Army of the Tennessee marched south to Yorkville, General Davis turned southeast and marched along the Van Wert - McPherson Road, which connected to the Mount Olivet Road, and eventually Dallas via Bishop\'s Bridge. Davis entered the north side of town and immediately advanced east to the New Hope Church Road, which is Old GA 381, and he established an intrenched line to the left of Major General James McPherson\'s Army of the Tennessee, which had occupied the city itself. Davis kind of plugged in the gap in the line between forces in Dallas and forces at New Hope Church and Pickett\'s Mill, which are to the northeast of the town.

properties.name: Battle of Dallas - Confederate Lines Block the Powder Springs Road
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickDallas, GAAt this point along Old US 278, the Confederate line crossed what was then called the Powder Springs Road. In doing so, the Confederate Army of Tennessee effectively blocked a direct route from Dallas to Powder Springs, which would have opened up a direct route into Atlanta from the due west.

properties.name: Battle of Dallas - General Dodge's Corps Enters the City
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickDallas, GABrigadier General Grenville Dodge\'s 16th Corps of the Army of the Tennessee marched out of Yorkville towards Dallas along with the rest of the Army of the Tennessee. The entire army marched along the Dallas - Yorkville Road or what is now US 278. As they approached the town, the army began to fan out. General Grenville Dodge\'s corps made up the center and continued to approach Dallas from the due west. By dawn on May 26, Brigadier General Dodge had reached this point on Pumpkinvine Creek near what is now Judge Foster Bridge on US 278/GA 6. By 10:00, General Dodge was across the creek. Four hours later, both Dodge\'s 16th Corps and Major General John Logan\'s 15th Corps had entered the central and southern parts of the city, where they began to encounter Confederate opposition primarily from cavalry on the southern flank and entrenched infantry and artillery in the center.

properties.name: Battle of Dallas - Pumpkinvine Baptist Church
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickDallas, GAMajor General John Logan\'s 15th Corps of the Army of the Tennessee camped here on May 25, 1864. This means that General John Logan had already forded Pumpkinvine Creek, but he and his troops still needed to cross Scoggins Creek and Lane Creek in order to reach Dallas. General Logan approached the town from the west - southwest, and he occupied the south side of the city by 2:00 on the 26th. There he was engaged by Confederate cavalry.

properties.name: Battle of Dallas - Southern Flank of the Confederate Lines
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickDallas, GAThe Confederate Army of Tennessee positioned the lines so that the southern flank would block the Villa Rica road south of Dallas, from which the Union forces could have turned east and threatened Powder Springs and could have achieved the potential to strike at Atlanta directly from the west.

properties.name: Battle of Dallas - Southern Flank of the Union Lines
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickDallas, GAFrom May 26 - June 1, 1864, Major General John Logan\'s 15th Corps of the Army of the Tennessee was posted along the ridges just to the north - northwest and down to this point. The Battle of Dallas raged for almost a week while New Hope Church lasted a mere two days and Pickett\'s Mill was over in a matter of hours. Entrenched Union forces successfully repulsed multiple Confederate advances and were able to withstand Confederate artillery, which shelled Dallas from ridges that loom to the east of town, such as Ray Mountain and Elsberry Mountain. The Battle of Dallas climaxed on May 28, when Lieutenant General William Hardee\'s Army Corps assaulted the 15th and 16th Army Corps\' fronts in a two-mile wave along the Villa Rica Road (now called GA 61 in most places). On June 1, General James McPherson\'s Army of the Tennessee was shifted north from the Dallas front as Sherman attempted to break out and march east towards the railroad, which was his crucial supply line.

properties.name: Battle of Dallas - The Annihilation of the Orphan Brigade
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickDallas, GAMay 28, 1864, on the ridge immediately to the west of this point in the town were the intrenched lines of the 1st Division of the 15th Union Army Corps and the 2nd Division of the 16th Union Army Corps. Beyond the ravine immediately to the east of this point were the lines of Major General William Bates\' division of Lieutenant General William Hardee\'s corps. Late that afternoon, Brigadier General Joseph Lewis\' Kentucky (Orphan) Brigade and Brigadier General Jesse Finley\'s Florida Brigade, made a desperate assault across the ravine and scaled the high ground to the west in an attempt to overrun the Union lines. The Kentucky Orphans suffered 51% casualties because they failed to recieve orders to withdraw. This was the most intense fighting at Dallas and eventually resulted in a Union victory. In the end, the Union forces suffered approximately 2,400 casualties and Confederate forces suffered approximately 3,000 casualties. The Rebels lost about twice as many troops at Dallas than they did at New Hope Church and Pickett\'s Mill combined.

properties.name: Battle of Dallas - Union Lines along the Powder Springs Road
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickDallas, GAAt this point on Old GA 6, almost underneath the GA 61 overpass, was the easternmost bulge in the Union lines at Dallas. From this point, the Federals could simultaneously defend the Villa Rica Road, or Old GA 61, and their supply lines running north and south through the town, as well as threaten the Powder Springs Road and Lost Mountain. Sherman could use this point as a tactical diversion by showing a somewhat significant force here, while shifting the main body of his troops to the northeast in order to flank the entrenched Confederate defenders. The Confederates were forced to check any possible advance east of here. Along this front, the fighting stalemated quickly and turned into a sub battle fought mostly by the artillery and snipers. By the way around here, the road names and highway numbers according to the map are wrong.

properties.name: Battle of New Hope Church
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickDallas, GALieutenant General John Hood’s Army Corps marched from Allatoona Pass and reached New Hope Church on May 25, just in time to check Brigadier General John Geary 2nd Division of the 20th Army Corps, commanded by Major General Joseph Hooker, which had detoured at Owen’s Mill enroute to Dallas via New Hope Church. General John Hood’s scouts spotted General John Geary’s force. The Confederates then entrenched and waited for General Geary to strike. Union troops advanced and struck Major General Alexander Stewart’s division along the road and Brigadier General Marcellus Stovall’s division in the church cemetery. General Joseph Hooker became disoriented and confused by poor maps and a lack of communications. General Hooker decided to wait until he received reinforcements and fresh orders. Sherman’s orders were to attack in attempt to flank the Rebels before they could fortify. Unfortunately for Hooker, the Confederate forces were already entrenched, and his pause gave them additional time to fortify their earthworks with logs, brush, and especially briars, which they would cut down and pile in front of their positions in order to help prevent infantry penetration of the lines. Hooker’s attempts to advance were repulsed. The battle, which lasted through the 26th, was fought during a bad thunderstorm, which made conditions even worse for the Federals, who were unable to dislodge the Rebel forces. Union losses included approximately 1,600 dead, while Confederate losses were between 500-750. Because of the battlefield defeats and jungle-like conditions of the area, such as the intense thunderstorms, heavy tree canopy, dense forests with near zero visability, dense underbrush with absolute-zero visability, swamps, lack of population, unbearable heat and humidity, the Union soldiers who fought at New Hope Church, Pickett’s Mill, and Dallas, nicknamed Paulding County, “The Hell Hole.” Some people live in the Big Apple, some live in the City of Angels, others live in the Windy City. I live in the “Hell Hole.” I vote we nickname our county, “Pick-up Truck Capitol of the World.” It may not be true, but it’s close and better than Hell Hole.

properties.name: Bro
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick Alpharetta, gaThis is where why brother and his wife live. He\'s my half-bro, he\'s half Thai, I noticed alot of Thai stuff on this website, so I thought I\'d mention that he works at his mom\'s restaurant, Royal Thai Cuisine. She\'s from Bangkok, my dad met her when he was in the Army (way before my time.)

properties.name: Brown's Mill
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickDallas, GANear this point on Possum Creek, once stood, Brown\'s Saw-mill, which was a landmark for military operations from May 25 - June 5, 1864. The Union\'s 23rd Army Corps moved here from Sligh\'s Mill & Tanyard via Burnt Hickory and Owens\' Mill. They then occupied the ridge line about one half-mile northeast of Brown\'s Mill. The 23rd A. C. held the ridge from May 26 - June 2 in active support of and in line with the 4th, 14th, and 20th Corps of the Army of the Cumberland. These troops faced the Army Corps of Generals Hood, Polk, and Hardee of General Johnston\'s Army of Tennessee. The 23rd essentially plugged the gap between Federal positions at New Hope Church and at Pickett\'s Mill.

properties.name: Brushy Mountain Tunnel
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick    Braswell, GAThis is an old railroad tunnel, built in 1912. It\'s about 800 feet long and 3 stories high. It\'s now apart of the Silver Comet bike/ped/equestrian trail. On a hot day, riding through this tunnel is a tremendous relief. Don\'t ride fast through it though because spring water drips into the entrances to the tunnel and there\'s always mud. The first time I rode through here, I rode fast and had the misfortune of wearing a white shirt with beige shorts. It looked like I crapped all over myself, and I didn\'t even know it until I got back to the truck.

properties.name: Burnt Hickory Community
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickDallas, GAThis community was also called Huntsville at one time. Union troops marching south out of Euharlee and Stilesboro marched upstream along Raccoon Creek to Murry Creek and some marched upstream along Jackson Creek to Marable Creek. Some accounts may erroneously use different names to describe these creeks because maps of the area were extremely lacking at the time. Burnt Hickory Community was a major rendezvous point for these troops marching south into Paulding County. They also met up with troops marching south out of Cartersville and Kingston, who were marching due south along the Dallas-Cartersville Road, now known as GA 61. Burnt Hickory was the last community Union troops would see before they reached New Hope and the town of Dallas. Everything in between was wilderness.

properties.name: CN Tower
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick250 Front Street West Toronto, ON

properties.name: Carter Road Trailhead
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick    Powder Springs, GAThis trailhead serves as the beginning of the Wild Horse Creek Trail, which follows Wild Horse Creek up to Wild Horse Creek Park on Macedonia Road. This is a beautiful trail which integrates with the extensive Powder Springs sidewalk network and provides easy access to the Silver Comet Trail for the northeast quarter of the city. This trail has some incredible views of wetlands including the mouth of Noses Creek and a two story wooden deck, which provides shade and shelter in addition to an excellent view of one of Powder Springs\' many swamps.

properties.name: Cedartown Trailhead
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick    Cedartown, GAThis is currently the eastern end of the portion of the Silver Comet Trail that runs from Cedartown to the Alabama state line. Construction is underway to connect the missing link between Cedartown and Rockmart. This is a nice trailhead with an old train station converted to a welcome center. It\'s also in the middle of downtown Cedartown, so it\'s very close to conveniences and amenities.

properties.name: Chinatown
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickLos Angeles, CA

properties.name: Colley House, 1864
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickHiram, GANear this point stood the Colley House, which briefly served as headquarters for Lieutenant General John Hood.

properties.name: Concord Road Trailhead
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick    Smyrna, GAThis is a very nice trailhead much like the one at Florence Road in Powder Springs with shelter, restrooms, and picnic tables. There is a very old covered bridge on Concord Road that spans Nickajack Creek. There are several other newer covered bridges in the area that have been reinforced or purposefully designed to look older. This is a very scenic area. In this general vicinity, and mainly between here and Heritage Park, is the main battle ground of the Battle of Ruff\'s Mill AKA the Battle of Smyrna. The battle was fought on the 4th of July 1864. By achieving victory at Ruff\'s Mill, Sherman\'s forces were able to move in and take Smyrna. Johnston\'s Confederate forces were forced to withdraw to what is known as the Chattahoochee Line in order to try to prevent Union attempts to ford and ferry the "Hooch." The Chattahoochee River was the last natural barrier that Sherman had to cross before taking Atlanta.

properties.name: Coot's Lake Beach Trailhead
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick    Rockmart, GAThis is the most heavily used trailhead in Polk County. Coot\'s Lake Beach is very popular because of the water park that operates here.

properties.name: Cousin Amie
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick Collegedale, TN

properties.name: Cousin Andrea
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick Ringgold, GA

properties.name: Cousin Tammy
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick Gray, GA

properties.name: Cousin Troy
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick McDonough, GAThis is actually the Henry County Courthouse, I know Troy lives in McDonough, but I\'m not sure where.

properties.name: Crossroads Presbyterian Church
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickDallas, GAThis church, which is located at Old Dallas - Acworth Road and Cedarcrest Road, which is the Old Burnt Hickory Road, was a key point for Union operations from May 25 - June 5, 1864. On June 2, the Union 23rd Army Corps marched northeast from Brown\'s Mill and marched southeast for 1.5 miles from here, which resulted in the successful outflanking of the Confederate forces. As a result, on June 4, the Rebels withdrew to positions in Cobb County, notably, Lost Mountain, Pine Mountain, and of course Kennesaw Mountain. Major General James McPherson\'s 15th and 16th Army Corps, which began moving northeast from Dallas on June 1, marched past this church on June 5 on their way to Big Shanty (Kennesaw) via Acworth.

properties.name: Dad's Birthplace
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick  Miami, FloridaMy father and my aunt both were born and raised in Miami. They lived in Coral Gables for several years, too. My grandparents moved here from Kentucky during the first land boom of the late 20s. They lived in different parts of Kentucky, but the same general region, but they met here in Florida. Grandpa was a business and economics professor at the University of Miami and Grandma worked at the bookstore. My dad went to Miami after he transferred back home from attempting med school at Tulane. So yeah, I\'m a die hard Miami Hurricane to the bitter end. You might say We got some Canes over here, huh huh huh!

properties.name: Dean Park Trailhead
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick    Rockmart, GACurrently, the Silver Comet Trail stops just west of Dean Sports Complex, and it picks back up in Cedartown, where it connects out to the Alabama State Line. Construction is currently underway to complete the Silver Comet Trail between Rockmart and Cedartown.

properties.name: Dean Rusk Middle School
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick Canton, GAI don\'t think any memories of this place are appropriate.

properties.name: Dillard Street Trailhead
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick    Powder Springs, GAThis isn\'t exactly a proper trailhead. This is just where the Lucille Creek Trail reconnects to the Silver Comet Trail. This spur trail is bisected by the Silver Comet Trail just west of here. It follows Lucille Creek from Shipp Road down to Old US 278, now called Powder Springs - Dallas Road. It then turns east and follows Old 278 into Downtown Powder Springs, where the name changes to Marietta Street. At both ends, the Lucille Creek Trail connects Powder Springs excellent sidewalk network, which they have invested tremendously in. This helps make the Silver Comet Trail very accessible for Powder Springs\' Downtown and Northwest portion.

properties.name: Dolphin Stadium
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick 2269 Dan Marino Blvd Miami Gardens, FLHome of the Dolphins and the Marlins. Here, the Marlins have won two World Series, while the Dolphins haven\'t won a SuperBowl since they moved from the Orange Bowl in downtown Miami. In fact, the Dolphins haven\'t won the SuperBowl in my lifetime. Formerly known as Joe Robbie and Pro Players Stadium, Dolphin Stadium is a great venue for football, and while it handles baseball just fine, it\'s obviously not a stadium designed for baseball. The Marlins organization and the City of Miami had talked earlier about building a new baseball stadium in downtown Miami, but I heard that the State of Florida wouldn\'t back the deal with state funds. As much as I would like to see the Marlins get the new stadium downtown, I have to back the governor on the decision he made. For Atlanta and Georgia it\'s easier....you have one team for each major sport and they\'re all in one city, which just happens to be the capitol and regional hub. In Florida, on the other hand, you\'ve got multiple teams in each sport spread all over the state, and none of them are in Tallahassee. So if you help build a stadium for the Marlins, why not the D-Rays or any other pro sports team for that matter? Enough preaching, I saw the Marlins play San Diego here one night with my sister and brother-in-law. The Padres shut them down that night (that was when the Marlins were still one of the newest teams in the Majors). They didn\'t get good until 1997, when they won it all. The Marlins have still never lost a post-season series. Florida seems to have become Atlanta\'s trouble team. Montreal used to be the team that would beat Atlanta without mercy no matter how good the Braves played against everone else. The Marlins have now seemed to fill that role. Think about it, the Marlins have won two world series and were born into a division that the Braves have owned ever since the Marlins came into the league. So while they\'ve never been able to win a division, they still have not been beaten in a post-season series. It\'s quite a coincidence that because Florida and Colorado came into the league, the Major Leagues were forced to realign divisions. Because of realignment, in order to have an even number of playoff contenders, the wild card slot had to be added. Florida has won two World Series by getting into the playoffs as a wild card team.

properties.name: Dr. Augustus Smith House Site, 1864
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick Acworth, GAIn this vicinity in 1864 stood the house of Dr. Augustus Smith. His house served as the headquarters of three Confederate generals. General William Hardee first set up his headquarters here on May 23 as his corps marched south into Paulding County from Stegall\'s Station (now known as Emerson). The next day, General John Hood set up his headquarters here as his troops were marching from Allatoona Pass to check Sherman\'s move towards Dallas at New Hope Church. On October 5, Major General Samuel French set up his headquarters here after he retreated from an aborted attempt to retake Allatoona Pass. He was enroute to meet up with General Hood at New Hope Church in order to combine forces to strike Union supply lines north of Atlanta. At this point Atlanta had already fallen, and the main defensive force was reeling to try to stop Sherman\'s March to the Sea, which ended in the capture of Savannah (Lincoln\'s 1864 Christmas present from Sherman). A smaller Confederate force broke out and marched north however, and attempted to harass Sherman\'s supply lines going into Atlanta.

properties.name: Esom Hill Road Trailhead
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick    Cedartown, GAThis is the westernmost and most remote trailhead on the Silver Comet Trail. On the Alabama side of the line, the trail is called the Chief Ladiga Trail. Currently, it\'s unpaved in Alabama. Crossing over into Alabama is like going back in time...................by an hour.

properties.name: Firehouse Food & Spirits
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick  Woodstock, GAThis was the closest bar to my house where I grew up. The owner knew several firefighters with the Woodstock FD, so that\'s why he named his place the Firehouse. They frequented the place quite often, too. It very quickly became the most popular tavern for local bikers, so it didn\'t take long to earn a rowdy reputation. They had lots of pool tables and karaoke. I saw the owner try to karaoke Pink Floyd\'s "Comfortably Numb" when he was totally hammered. It was a sad sight and painful to listen to.

properties.name: Florence Road Trailhead
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick    Powder Springs, GAThis is one of the nicer trailheads with shelter, restrooms, and picnic tables.

properties.name: Floyd Road Trailhead
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick    Mableton, GAThis is a great trailhead with the Silver Comet Depot, which is a cool store, I think they also have a location in Rockmart. I\'m frankly surprised that they haven\'t tried to put some kind of shop like this at one of the Powder Springs trailheads.

properties.name: Folks
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick Woodstock, GAThis is where my parents live. They have a big house with a back deck with an awesome view. The back yard is bounded by Rose Creek. When we have sleet or freezing rain, they\'re just screwed because of the extreme incline of the driveway and street.

properties.name: Fontaine Road Trailhead
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick    Smyrna, GAThis trailhead is the closest trailhead on the Silver Comet to Heritage Park, which is one of the most popular parks in the Smyrna area. If you are hiking rather than bicycling, I highly recommend riding down just a little farther to Heritage Park. You can access the Silver Comet via its hiking trails, which are really cool. They don\'t allow bicycles on those trails (like that stops anyone around here anyway).

properties.name: Fort King George State Historic Site
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick1600 Wayne St Darien, GASouthern outpost of the British Empire in North America from 1721-1727. A palisaded earthen fort, barracks, and a cypress blockhouse were built in 1721 by soldiers under the command of Colonel John "Tuscarora Jack" Barnwell. The fort caught fire in 1725, damaging the blockhouse and destroying the barracks. It was partially rebuilt in 1727, but was promptly abandoned as the garrison was moved to South Carolina. Although the outpost was never attacked, the garrison suffered heavily from malaria and the unforgiving environment of the marsh. General James Oglethorpe, the founder of Georgia, brought Scottish Highlanders to the abandoned site in 1736, just three years after the colony was established. Their settlement, which was named Darien, survived and went on to become the global export center of lumber until 1925. Near the fort site was a Guale town called Talaje and later a Spanish mission called Santo Domingo de Talaje, which was built in 1595. It was destroyed during the Guale uprising of 1597. The Spaniards returned and rebuilt the mission, but it was destroyed and abandoned permanently in 1661.

properties.name: George Darby House, 1864
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickHiram, GANear this point, stood the house of George Darby, which briefly served as headquarters for Brigadier General Patrick Cleburne.

properties.name: Georgia Dome
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick Atlanta, GAHome of the Falcons and the annual Peach Bowl. I think it\'ll host next year\'s Final Four as well. Sometimes they have concerts here, but the acoustics are terrible compared to Philips Arena. I\'ve been to the last two Peach Bowls here because they both featured Miami. I wasn\'t too happy with Miami\'s performance against LSU, it kind of reminded me of the only Falcons game I went to. They were playing San Francisco, and we were a little bit late, so by the time we walked in, it was already 14-0 49ers. Oh well, at least we got to see the Falcons only points, which came from a field goal. I think Frisco wound up beating us 49-3 or something like that, and to rub it in even more, that was when Deion had just gone to the Niners, ouch! The only other Falcons games I\'ve seen were at the old A-FC Stadium. The teams should clue you in to how long ago it was. I saw them play the St. Louis Cardinals and the LA Rams back in the 80s. The Dome has also hosted a couple of SuperBowls. My dad worked at them as a nacho vendor. He didn\'t get to see any of the game, but unlike me, he can say that he\'s actually been to the SuperBowl. He didn\'t care anyway since the Falcons weren\'t in it. We also got to keep the left over cheese, so we had these giant jars of yellow stadium nacho cheese for months at our house. I\'m surprised that I haven\'t suffered a heart attack or massive stroke by now.

properties.name: Georgia State University
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick33 Gilmer St SE Atlanta, GA 30303I\'ll be attending Grad School here Fall 06.

properties.name: Grandma Mac's Birthplace
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickAlexandria, KYThis is where my paternal grandmother was born. I originally thought that it was farther away from Cincinnati than it actually is. One of her relatives, either her father, uncle, or grandfather, I think ran a bus service from Alexandria to Newport, which is right across the river from Cincinnati, and that\'s where the Cambell County Courthouse is. Her father suffered from chronic resperatory illnesses, so he decided to move to Miami because he believed that the subtropical climate would help him to have a much better quality of life. Jobs were also easier to find down there than in the Cincinnati Tri-State area.

properties.name: Grandpa Mac's Birthplace
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickErlanger, KYThis is where my grandfather was from, most of his family lived in the Cincinnati area. He attended Georgetown College, which is close to Kentucky University. Not long after he graduated from college, he moved to Miami.

properties.name: Great-grandparents Birthplace
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickLafayette, AL

properties.name: Great-grandparents Birthplace
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickAbbeville, AL

properties.name: Great-grandparents Birthplace
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickRussellville, KY

properties.name: Great-grandparents Birthplace
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickNorwood, OHNorwood is one of those cities that has been using its eminent domain authority to benefit private developers. Feel free to e-mail them to tell them that they suck.

properties.name: Great-grandparents Birthplace
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickBuena Vista, GA

properties.name: Great-grandparents Birthplace
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickMilan, INWasn\'t Milan HS one of the teams from the movie Hoosiers? I don\'t know, it\'s been so long since I\'ve seen it. If I were from Indiana, I would have a shirt that would say "Hoosier Daddy." I\'m sure some fraternity in Bloomington already has them. Whatever, this is actually Bearcat country here anyway.

properties.name: Heritage Park Trailhead
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick    Smyrna, GAFrom this park, you can access the Silver Comet Trail on foot. The trails, which are technically forbidden for bicycles take you through the heavy forest, while a boardwalk takes you through wetlands until you cross Nickajack Creek. The trail runs along the creek and near where it accesses the Silver Comet Trail, there are the ruins of a mill that once operated on the creek. At the park entrance, there are nice sheltered areas, nice restrooms, and historical and natural interpretive information about the park and the Smyrna area. This area saw intense fighting during early July of 1864 as part of the Battle of Ruff\'s Mill/Smyrna.

properties.name: High Shoals Falls
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickWaterfalls near High Shoals Church.

properties.name: Highway 41 from Ramblin Man by the Allman Brothers Band
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickMacon, GA

properties.name: Hiram Trailhead
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick    Hiram, GAThis is the most heavily used trailhead in Paulding County.

properties.name: I-10 & I-55 Near Monchac, LA (West of NOLA)
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickNew Orleans, LAWhile the bridge\'s style is unimpressive, driving on this stretch of freeway is an unforgetable experience. Better have plenty of gas, and if you even think you might have car trouble, don\'t attempt it. After a couple of miles, you start to ask yourself, will I ever see dry land again? The combined continuous length of this bridge including the 10-55 interchange is 181,157 feet. Really, the simple fact that New Orleans can be connected to the rest of the nation over "land" is an engineering marvel in and of itself.

properties.name: KVLY-TV Mast
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickBlanchard, ND

properties.name: Kennesaw Mountain National Battlefield Park
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick     Marietta, GAKennesaw rises 1,000 feet above the surrounding Piedmont Plateau to the south and the Ridge and Valley region to the north. The park was created to protect, interpret, and memorialize the Battle of Kennesaw Mountain fought in June 1864. In addition to history, the park contains an extensive trail network through hardwood forests that have been left undisturbed for almost a century. The views from the peak of Kennesaw are incredible, and the view of the Atlanta skyline points to its strategic significance during the Civil War. Total trail lengths are approximately 16 miles, and the peak of the mountain is 1,808 feet above sea level. Significant geographic features pertinent to the battle include Kennesaw Mountain, Little Kennesaw Mountain, Pigeon Hill, Burnt Hickory Road, Dallas Road (Highway 120), Noses Creek, Kolb\'s Farm, John Ward Creek, and Cheatham Hill. Cheatham Hill is where the worst of the intense fighting took place. Union troops dubbed it the "Dead Angle," because it was at Cheatham Hill, that a massive Union force attempted to break a deeply entrenched Confederate force, and wave after wave of Union troops were cut down by well timed volleys from the Rebel troops. The State of Illinois has erected an impressive memorial in rememberance of the tremendous sacrifice that their troops gave at Cheatham Hill. The soldiers\' accounts that I read about the battle in the museum and especially about Cheatham Hill were so horrifyingly sick, that I just about broke down reading it. I just had to stop. War is Hell.

properties.name: Kennesaw State University
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickKennesaw, GAHome of the Hooters!! Just kidding, we are the Owls. Notice this place is right off I-75, if you\'re a single guy, on your way to or from Atlanta, exit here, and just drive through the area for a few minutes. You won\'t regret it. My boss told me that when his brother drives through this area, he prays for heavy traffic so he can gawk at all the hotties stuck around him. I don\'t think he\'s alone!!

properties.name: Last Year's Vacation
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick11730 Gulf Blvd Treasure Island, FLTropic Terrace Apartments on Treasure Island. This place is pretty cool. I went to a Devil Rays game in St. Pete, Fort DeSoto, and I played tons of shuffleboard. It\'s like curling, only with plastic discs instead of stones and it\'s hotter than hell instead of freezing cold, and you don\'t slide yourself down the court. Well, I guess it\'s nothing like curling after all, but it\'s more fun than I thought it would be. The beach was great, too, but the water was so warm that it was like bath water, so it wasn\'t much relief from the heat.

properties.name: Little River Elementary School
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick Woodstock, GAThis is where I started school. We were the friggin Raiders, then after I went to Middle School, the wusses changed the name to the Eagles. That was \'91, so Raiders junk was associated with gangs and NWA I guess. Little River will always be Raiders to me.

properties.name: Major Engagement
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickDallas, GABattle of Dallas. Near the southern flank of the Confederate Army of Tennessee in late May 1864.

properties.name: Major Engagement
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickDallas, GASight of the destruction of Kentucky\'s "Orphan Brigade" during the Battle of Dallas in 1864.

properties.name: Major Engagement
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickDallas, GABattle of Dallas. Near the northern flank of the Confederate Army of Tennessee, late May 1864. There\'s a ridge line connecting a couple of mountains that loom over the town just to our east. From here, along that line connecting to where I\'ve placed the southern flank, the Confederate defenders garrisoned the ridge line and shelled the town. Union forces dug in and retaliated with artillery fire of their own, and they successfully countered assaults by Confederate infantry and cavalry. The rebels failed in their attempt to stop Sherman\'s army from reaching Marietta and his ultimate prize, Atlanta. The front at the time began here and ran down past the main infantry lines and connected to artillery and cavalry outposts south of the city. The front was approximately 10 miles long, and the fighting lasted from May 25-June 2, 1864. After June 2, Union forces moved to Kennesaw Mountain to attempt to flank the Confederate forces withdrawing to a point from which they thought that they might be able to prevent the capture of Atlanta.

properties.name: Mark Light Field
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick Coral Gables, FLHome of the Hurricanes baseball team. With 4 College World Series titles, they have only one less National Championship than the football team. The University has planned a multi-million dollar renovation for the baseball facility, and Alex Rodriguez, ever the gentleman, has kicked in over million for the project. Therefore, they will rename the facility, Alex Rodriguez Park.

properties.name: Martin Trailhead
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick    Cedartown, GA

properties.name: Maternal Grandparents Birthplace
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickColumbus, GABoth of my mother\'s parents plus a couple of my great-grandparents were born in Columbus. If I had to name one place in the country where I had the deepest roots, I\'d say Columbus even though I\'ve never lived there myself. Columbus is home to the largest infantry training base in the US, Fort Benning. Columbus is also the largest city in West Central Georgia. It was built at the head of navigation on the Chattahoochee River.

properties.name: Mavell Road Trailhead
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick    Smyrna, GAOriginally, this was where the Silver Comet Trail began in the east.

properties.name: My Birthplace
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick417 Third Avenue, Albany, GAThis is where my uncle, who now lives in Kentucky, and my mother were born and raised. I was born here also, but my mom already lived in Atlanta at the time. She just wanted to go back home to have me so she could be in familiar surroundings. We moved back to Atlanta after things settled down. Dad\'s job was in Atlanta, so he stayed behind while my grandparents took care of my mom. My grandparents moved here from Columbus after WWII. Albany is the home of the late Ray Charles. It was devastated by a massive flooding of the Flint River in the mid-90s. Chehaw Park is one of the best zoos in the world. It was designed by local zoologist, Jack Hannah.

properties.name: My Brother's Birthplace
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickAtlanta, GA

properties.name: My Old House
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickWoodstock, GAI lived here for 23 years before I moved to Dallas, GA.

properties.name: My Sister's Birthplace
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickNashville, TN

properties.name: New Ebenezer Community
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick2887 Ebenezer Rd Rincon, GAThe community of New Ebenezer was established in 1736 on the Savannah River about 30 miles upriver from Savannah. This community is home to the oldest public building in the State of Georgia. New Ebenezer established Georgia\'s first public school, and in 1737, it\'s first public orphanage. The community\'s founders were Protestant Austrians who fled Salzburg in 1734 because of religious persecution. After consulting with the colony\'s founder, General James Oglethorpe, the Salzburgers decided to establish their community of Ebenezer six miles up Ebenezer Creek. Outbreaks of disease forced the settlers to move the community to the current site of New Ebenezer, near the banks of the Savannah. The new site was a success, and it grew to a population of over 1600. Each settler family was given a Mulberry Tree from the Trustee\'s Garden in Savannah for the purposes of producing silk. Although, James Oglethorpe\'s vision was of the entire colony establishing a silk industry in the New World, most silk production failed. New Ebenezer was one of the very few exceptional communities where silk production actually thrived. The only thing left of the original community is Jerusalem Lutheran Church, it\'s cemetery, and a house. The current church was built in 1769. During the Revolution, British Colonel Archibald Campbell captured, burned, and looted New Ebenezer. The British used the community as a prison camp and the church for a hospital, storehouse, and stable. In 1782, Colonial forces under the command of General "Mad" Anthony Wayne drove the British from New Ebenezer. In July of that same year, the Georgia Legislature met in the church. After the war, most of the Salzburgers left the gutted town. One of the original Salzburger colonists, John Treutlen, was an Amerian patriot who became the first governor of the State of Georgia, and was subsequently murdered in South Carolina by Tories in 1782. Many Salzburger descendants return every year on the anniversary of their ancestors\' arrival in Georgia on March 12.

properties.name: Oakdale Road Trailhead
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick    Smyrna, GAThis proposed trailhead will act as the eastern end of the Silver Comet Trail as well as the beginning of the Silver Comet - Cumberland Connector Trail, which will eventually access part of the Kennesaw Mountain - Chattahoochee River Trail. This trail will run through the heart of Cobb County and connect Kennesaw Mountain National Battlefield Park in Marietta to the Chattahoochee National Recreation Area, which straddles the river in various parts of Metro Atlanta.

properties.name: Paulding Chamber of Commerce Trailhead
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick    Dallas, GAThis is the most heavily used trailhead in Dallas.

properties.name: Paulding County GIS
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickPaulding County\'s Administration/Regions Bank Building. Location of the GIS Division of the IT Department.

properties.name: Paulding County Seat
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickDallas, GAPaulding County, Georgia was carved out of Cherokee County December 3, 1832. It was named after John Paulding, one of the three captors of Major John Andre, the leader of a British spy ring who went ashore at West Point to pay Benedict Arnold 20,000 pounds to cede the fort to the British forces. Van Wert, now in Polk County, was the original county seat. Van Wert was named after Isaac Van Wart, another one of the captors of Major Andre. David Williams was the other member of the trio of captors. When Polk County was carved out of Paulding and Floyd Counties in 1851, Dallas became the Paulding County seat. The courthouse was built in 1892. The courthouse that was used during Reconstruction is now the Dallas Masonic Lodge, which is directly across Old GA 61 or Main Street.

properties.name: Philips Arena (The Omni, RIP)
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick Atlanta, GAI\'ve never actually been inside Philips Arena, but I\'ve walked past it a couple of times since it\'s right next to the Georgia Dome and World Congress Center. It\'s connected to the Omni Hotel and the CNN Center. I had dinner there and got a kickass hoody from the Braves store there when I went to the Peach Bowl just before New Years. Well, I think the reason that I\'ve never been to Philips is that the Hawks have sucked in recent years, and I\'m even less of a hockey fan than a basketball fan, so I doubt I\'d ever go to a Thrashers game unless the tickets were free, even if they were a top team, which they\'re not. They\'ve had several good concerts there, but I\'ve never been to any. Most of the concerts that I\'ve been to were at Lakewood. The Omni however, which sat precisely where Philips sits now, I\'ve been to several times. Mostly to Hawks games back in the 80s and a few in the early 90s. The Hawks had playoff caliber teams back then with Nique, Kevin Willis, Spud Webb, and Doc Rivers, but ever since that crew left, the Hawks haven\'t been able to get off the ground. My parents told me that they took me to a hockey game when I was little, back when we had the Flames, but I don\'t remember it. Of course, the Flames had a good team after they moved to Calgary. I remember the last time I went to the Omni, I saw Soundgarden back in 96 or 97. They were doing a makeup show for the one they did in Atlanta that was somewhat disrupted by the Olympic hoopla. I think it was right around the time that they came out with their last album. Well, after that, they had Metallica, which I didn\'t get to go to, and then they tore the place down, to build Philips.

properties.name: Pickett's Mill Battlefield State Park
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick   Dallas, GAThis state park has been described as one of the best preserved Civil War battlefields in the Eastern US. This is in stark contrast to the other two battles that took place here in Paulding County, New Hope Church and Dallas. Of course, Dallas has been developed for years, and the city continues to grow, but New Hope Community has seen only recent development, but it has been dramatic, and now most of the former battlefield is paved over. I guess we could now call it the Battle of Publix Shopping Center. Metro Atlanta has a bad reputation for paving over its history. Enough preaching. The Battle of Picketts Mill was an absolute fiasco as Union forces attempting to "turn the corner" of the Dallas-New Hope Line walked into a trap. Ironically, the most prominent factor that led to their defeat was a lack of good maps of the area. Union officers marched their men through a dense forest in an attempt to engage the opposing Confederate line. In order to do this, they had to march down an extremely steep ravine, and climb back up the steep creek bank on the other side of Picketts Mill Creek. They attempted this under direct fire from perfectly positioned Confederate artillery. The result was an awful bloodbath, from which the Union officers reluctantly withdrew. A paraphrased description complete with personal corrections and some of my own commentary thrown in: Pickett’s Mill is named after Benjamin and Malachi Pickett who moved to the rugged and densely forested ridges west of Kennesaw (known then as Big Shanty) to build a business and provide for their families. General William Tecumseh Sherman moved there to avoid a battle. Late on a Friday afternoon in Spring of 1864, 14,000 Union troops from Major General Oliver Howard’s 4th Army Corps moved towards the Pickett’s farm and grist mill on Pickett’s Mill Creek (some mistakenly call it Little Pumpkinvine Creek) and one of the worst Federal defeats during the Atlanta Campaign. Concerning the confusion of the creeks, most people also confuse Little Pumpkinvine Creek with Pumpkinvine Creek. I read a website that described the Battle of Pickett’s Mill, and it claimed that Pumpkinvine Creek empties about four miles from it’s source. Whoever wrote that must have been referring to Little Pumpkinvine Creek or some other creek because Pumpkinvine Creek flows from its source in the Southwest part of Paulding County to the Northeast corner of the county and beyond into Bartow County. I know for a fact that the distance must be at least ten miles; probably closer to 20 miles from source to mouth. The background story behind the Battle of Pickett’s Mill began ten days earlier, when General William Sherman occupied Kingston in Bartow County. It took a mere two weeks for General Sherman to march half the distance from Chattanooga to Atlanta. He successfully avoided General Joseph Johnston’s entrenched lines by outflanking him at Dalton and Resaca. General Johnston fell back to Allatoona Pass where he set a trap for Sherman. Allatoona Pass was a narrow railroad cut through a mountain and whoever controlled the pass controlled the bridge over Allatoona Creek (now apart of Allatoona Lake). This point is eight miles east of Kingston. The Western & Atlantic Railroad was Sherman’s supply line. Unfortunately for Johnston, Sherman had been stationed at Marietta before the war, and he was well aware of the inevitability of the Confederates’ intention to set a trap at Allatoona Pass. Regardless, Sherman had to find a way to dislodge the Rebels from Allatoona Pass so that he could get his army back on the railroad. Sherman decided to march south into the Paulding County wilderness. This was extremely risky because it presented the problem of trying to feed an army of 100,000 deep in enemy territory. Plus as his distance from the rail line increased, the number of soldiers he would need to divert to wagon train guard duty had to increase proportionally. These wagon lines became more and more vulnerable the deeper he went into Paulding County. General Joseph Hooker encountered resistance near a church northeast of Dallas. General Hooker was confused by inaccurate maps and poor communications, so he decided to wait for reinforcements. Sherman orders an attack in an attempt to outflank the Confederates before they get a chance to fortify the position. The Battle of New Hope Church shocks Sherman because he wasn’t expecting stiff resistance there. Union forces were caught flat footed by Confederate forces who had rapidly moved southwest from Allatoona Pass to check Sherman’s flanking maneuver, which had put Powder Springs in jeopardy along with a direct route into Atlanta from the due west. Federal troops quickly began to suffer from lack of supplies. Sherman ordered General Oliver Howard to attack the left flank of the Confederate Army. General George Thomas, Commander of the Army of the Cumberland and General Howard scouted the area just to the northeast of New Hope Church. They decided to attack what appeared to be the end of the Confederate line at Pickett’s Mill. With Pickett’s Mill Creek to the east, troops under the command of Brigadier General William Hazen begin an assault on the Confederate line, which was heavily fortified. Although General William Hazen knew the advance was a mistake, he followed orders anyway. General Hazen’s soldiers were up against one of the South’s best commanders, Brigadier General Patrick Cleburne. At 4:30 PM, Hazen approaches the Confederate line. Many of his troops got lost in the dense forest during the initial advance and wound up east of the intended objective. Hazen’s support on the right flank was pinned down by dismounted Confederate cavalry firing from the top of a ravine down into the Union troops below who were trying to cross the creek. Very rapidly, the bulk of Hazen’s force found themselves stranded in one of the few open areas of the battlefield, and they subsequently came under merciless fire. Reinforcements from the main Union line were held up by the thick underbrush. When Hazen realized that reinforcements wouldn\'t arrive in time, he ordered a retreat. At 6:00 PM, General Thomas Woods ordered a second attack. Although Hazen had made some advances, the second attack ended in disaster when Colonel William Gibson’s brigade was totally routed by General Patrick Cleburne’s men. Brigadier General Hiram Granbury successfully repulsed Federal attacks and he requested and received permission from General Cleburne to sweep the area in front of the Confederate earthworks for Union troops. At 10:00 PM General Hiram Granbury’s Texans began the counterattack. The Federals got off one volley against the counterattack and then fell into full retreat. After the battle, Patrick Cleburne estimated 3,000 Union casualties, with at least 1,500 of them killed. By contrast, the Rebels lost only about 500 troops. Therefore, the Battle of Pickett’s Mill was a decisive victory for the Confederacy. For the first time during the Atlanta Campaign, Sherman had to worry about a possible retreat. He realized that he had driven too deep into unfamiliar territory and that he had no choice but to try to break out to the east-northeast in order to get back to the rail line, even if it meant besieging the Confederate fortifications at Allatoona Pass. On May 29, Sherman began to shift troops along the Dallas Line to the north and east to prepare for a break out. Fortunately for Sherman, on June 1, he received the news that Allatoona Pass had been taken by General George Stoneman’s cavalry with little resistance. In fact, precisely because Sherman had driven so deep south, the Confederate Army of Tennessee had to scramble most of the defensive force that they had at Allatoona Pass down to Paulding County in order to prevent Sherman from taking Powder Springs and approaching Atlanta directly from the west. Only a token force could be left to defend Allatoona Pass. The Confederates were also trying to prevent Sherman from taking Marietta and Smyrna, but he wound up taking them anyway along with the ultimate prize, Atlanta.

properties.name: Pumpkinvine Trestle
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick    Dallas, GAOld rail bridge with beautiful view of Pumpkinvine Creek. The bridge is apart of the Silver Comet bike/ped/equestrian trail. The bridge was built in 1901. It\'s 750 feet long and 126 feet high.

properties.name: Rambo Trailhead
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick    Dallas, GASilver Comet Trailhead at Rambo Nursery. Silver Comet is an old passenger rail line that used to connect Birmingham and New York via Atlanta. This is the trailhead that I use most often. Most people who want to see the Pumpkinvine Trestle and Brushy Mountain Tunnel get on the trail here. Mount Olivet Road Trailhead, which was on the main drag in my community was once popular, especially for riders and hikers that wanted to visit the tunnel, but the DOT came in and tunneled under Mt. Olivet Road and did away with the trailhead in doing so. There was supposed to be a new trailhead with a paved parking lot going in by now, but I haven\'t noticed any clearing of the site. I guess they\'re just using funds for the trail itself right now, which is under construction between Rockmart and Cedartown.

properties.name: Richard Sailors Parkway Trailhead
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick    Powder Springs, GA

properties.name: Rockmart Trailhead
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick    Rockmart, GASituated in downtown Rockmart on Euharlee Creek, this trailhead has immediate access to conveniences and amenities. A couple of bridges over the creek access a nice park. This is by far the best trailhead in Polk County. I think Rockmart does a better job than any other city on the trail when it comes to integrating the Silver Comet into the city. As a result, I\'ve noticed that most active people that live in Rockmart ride their bicycles everywhere in town, even if it\'s not that close to the trail. Some might argue that Powder Springs has done a better job, but I would counter that Powder Springs has much deeper pockets than Rockmart because of the size of the town. Then again, Rockmart can acquire land at much lower cost than Powder Springs, so I guess you could make a case for either one. Regardless, this is my personal favorite trailhead.

properties.name: Russ Chandler Stadium
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick Atlanta, GAThis is where Georgia Tech plays baseball. I go here to watch the Canes play when Miami is in town, now that Miami is in the ACC. The last time I went, they got blown off the field (I think because it was so cold that night), but they wound up winning that series. By the way, our coach who has won multiple College World Series Titles, Jim Morris, was previously Tech\'s baseball coach.

properties.name: Savannah
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickSavannah, GAThe original capitol of the 13th British Colony. This is still the only city of any size on the Georgia Coast. The Saint Patrick\'s Day celebration here rivals that of New York, Chicago, and Boston.

properties.name: Scarface
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickMiami, FL

properties.name: Seaboard Drive Trailhead
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick    Dallas, GAThis trailhead is often confused with the Hiram Trailhead because the Hiram Trailhead is located off of Seaboard Avenue. I\'ve seen directions to this online given by Seaboard Avenue.

properties.name: Sequoyah High School
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick Canton, GAGo Chiefs!

properties.name: Shady Grove Baptist Church
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickDallas, GANear this present day church, there used to be an intersection of the old Dallas-Burnt Hickory Road, and a road that used to lead east to New Hope via a bridge over Pumpkinvine Creek and Owen\'s Mill. On May 25, 1864, Major General John Geary\'s 2nd Division of the 20th Army Corps followed by Brigadier General Alpheus Williams\' 1st Division of the 20th Army Corps turned east after a brief exchange of fire with Confederate scouts at Owen\'s Mill. These scouts were outposts of the army corps under the command of Lieutenant General John Hood, who had marched from Allatoona Pass to New Hope Church, where he dug in. Generals John Geary and Alpheus Williams were reinforced by the 4th and 23rd Army Corps. Major General Geary\'s 2nd Division assaulted the entrenched Confederate line that was posted in and near the New Hope Church Cemetery.

properties.name: Shipp Road Trailhead
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick    Powder Springs, GAThis isn\'t exactly a proper trailhead. This is just where the Lucille Creek Trail starts. This spur trail is bisected by the Silver Comet Trail. It follows Lucille Creek from Shipp Road down to Old US 278, now called Powder Springs - Dallas Road. It then turns east and follows Old 278 into Downtown Powder Springs, where the name changes to Marietta Street. At both ends, the Lucille Creek Trail connects Powder Springs excellent sidewalk network, which they have invested tremendously in. This helps make the Silver Comet Trail very accessible for Powder Springs\' Downtown and Northwest portion. The Lucille Creek Trail also connects to the Silver Comet Trail directly from Marietta Street via a spur that runs down Dillard Street.

properties.name: Sis
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick 1662 132nd Way Davie, FLThis is where my sister, Sumitra lives. Her house is a mansion, I\'m not exaggerating. It\'s nice, but tropical weather can be a bitch.

properties.name: Sligh's Mill, Pottery, & Tanyard
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickDallas, GANot far from this intersection stood Sligh\'s Mill, which was a key landmark and reference point for Union troops who were marching south into the wilderness towards Dallas and New Hope.

properties.name: South Cobb Drive Trailhead
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick    Smyrna, GASince this trailhead is a shopping center, it\'s probably the most popular trailhead, if not the most heavily used trailhead on the Silver Comet Trail. It\'s also the most convenient trailhead to get to from the freeway. This intersection is on a hill, and there\'s an awesome view of Atlanta\'s skyline, especially on cool, dry days.

properties.name: The Big Chicken
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickCorner of US 41 & GA 120, Marietta, GAThis KFC location is the premier landmark in Marietta.

properties.name: The Briar Patch
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick Hiram, GABest Barbeque in the county.

properties.name: The Chop Shop (A-FC Stadium, RIP)
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick  Atlanta, GAHome of the Braves and Falcons from 1966, when the team moved here from Milwaukee until after the 1996 Olympic Games, when the Olympic Stadium was converted to Turner Field. The Falcons moved to the Georgia Dome when it was built in 1991. Here, Hank Aaron broke Babe Ruth\'s homerun record (before my time). When I was a kid, Dale Murphy and Bob Horner were the big stars for the Braves. They were terrible in the 80s, it got so bad that Ted Turner even held races at the stadium with ostrich powered chariots as a promotional to get fans to come watch the games. Then in the 90s, everything changed, we got Bobby Cox as manager and John Schuerholz as GM, and that relationship has produced results: 14 consecutive division titles, 5 pennants, & a world championship aint bad considering what we had just one year before our first pennant, last place. I remember one night after going to see a game against San Diego in \'91, people were out of their heads, the stadium was so loud that I couldn\'t even think...I\'m not exaggerating. Everyone was doing the Tomahawk Chop, shouting that war chant, I mean at the top of their lungs..10s of thousands of people, it got pretty roudy. Anyway, that whole season, we were one loss away from being put out of the division race by the Dodgers. We caught them and barely stayed ahead. That night against the Padres, we were losing, then we tied it, and in the bottom of the ninth, I think it was Ron Gant that hit a 2 run homer to win the game. I\'ve been to many concerts, but I\'ve never heard a place so loud in all my days. The fans were so excited that they continued bellowing that war chant out into the parking lot, and there\'s a tunnel that connects two lots under Capitol Avenue, and I remember the mass of people walking through there doing that war chant at the top of their lungs and hearing it echo through the tunnel. See, back in those days, we couldn\'t even comprehend that an Atlanta team would do well in sports, sure the Hawks were decent, and we had a few individual stars like Nique, Aaron, Niekro, and Murphy, but never so much as a first place finish. The first Braves batter to step to the plate here was Felipe Alou, and the last batter to step up to the plate in the regular season was his son, Moises Alou, playing for Montreal. His father, Felipe was the Expos manager at the time, too. Freaky. The final game was honorably a World Series game played against New York in 1996.

properties.name: The Doors L A Woman
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickLos Angeles, CA

properties.name: The Orange Bowl
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick Miami, FLHome of the Hurricanes.

properties.name: The Rat Hole
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick Atlantic City, NJThe nickname of my football stadium for my FFLWA (Fantasy Football League of West Atlanta) Team, the New Jersey Rats (formerly the Akron Rubbers).

properties.name: Trainspotting
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickEdinburgh, Scotland

properties.name: Travis Tritt's House
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickPowder Springs, GAI\'m not really a big country music fan, but I know alot of people are, so here\'s his house. Just be careful if you want to use this map, where it says "61," well I think that\'s supposed to be Ridge Road, which is NOT a state highway, and it\'s definitely not 61. You can\'t get to Powder Springs off of 61.

properties.name: Tropicana Field
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick One Tropicana Dr St Petersburg, FLHome of the Tampa Bay Devil Rays and at one time, the Tampa Bay Lightning of the NHL. It was originally called the Sun Coast Dome and later the Thunder Dome. This was a great hockey venue for a good hockey team, but this is a terrible baseball venue for a terrible baseball team. I went there last year when I was staying on Treasure Island for vacation. They got beat by New York, which was one of the teams that they actually played well against last season. I love the coloring of the place and the design, but I just don\'t like the idea of playing baseball and football in a dome down here. I love the Falcons, and I\'m glad they don\'t have to share with the Braves anymore, but I just don\'t get it. The climate is awesome down here and in Atlanta. If they can play baseball and football out in the open in New York, Chicago, Washington, Philadelphia, and Boston, why can\'t they play out in the open down here? It gets just as hot and humid up there in the summer. I\'ll give Detroit and Minneapolis a free pass on this, but why we have domes in Atlanta, Tampa, and New Orleans is beyond me. Don\'t give me the hot and humid excuse either, Miami never used a dome and Houston has done away with theirs.

properties.name: Turner Field
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick Atlanta, GAHome of the Braves. It was the Olympic Stadium built for the Centennial Olympic Games in 1996. Ironically, baseball, which was the only Olympic event that I got to see, was played at the old AFC Stadium. Last summer, my brother-in-law took me to a game, and since his friend\'s grandmother knows Henry Aaron, we were somehow able to get Aaron\'s seats. We ended up sitting literally behind homeplate. I don\'t mean a couple rows back or so, I mean it was us, then the wall, then the umpire\'s butt. Best seats I\'ve ever had. They played the Cubs that night, and after a rain delay of 1.5 hours with some bad lightning, they ended up winning the game. The first game I got to see here was a playoff game against Florida in 1997. We won the game, but of course we lost that series because the Marlins went on to win their first World Series that year. I miss the memories of A-FC Stadium, but this ballpark has better seats and is more stylish. It\'s truly a stadium built for baseball whereas A-FC was designed to save money by utilizing the generic, bland, coliseum style stadium for multiple sports, of course, mainly baseball and football. Ironically, Turner Field was originally that Olympic Stadium, which had that same bland coliseum shape. They just tore out some pieces in order to shape it how it is today.

properties.name: Uncle Spencer
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick This is where my uncle lives in Kimper, Kentucky. He actually lives on a mountain, and his wife is a real coal miner\'s daughter from West Virginia, which along with Virginia, is very close to here. This area was the site of the real life feud between the Hatfields and McCoys. When my uncle moved here from Atlanta, he was shocked that it was a real story, I guess he thought it was a myth or something.

properties.name: Van Wert Trailhead
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick    Van Wert, GAVan Wert, founded in 1838, was made the original county seat of Paulding County four years after it was carved out of Cherokee County in 1832. When Polk County was carved out of Paulding and Floyd Counties in 1851, Van Wert became apart of the new county. For Paulding, the county seat was moved to Dallas. Three years later, in 1854, the Polk County Seat was moved to Cedartown. Van Wert was the first town in the state to have its own water system, which was installed in 1886. During and immediately after the Civil War, Van Wert was the only town in this vicinity, however, during the post war economic recovery, the railroad was put through the area to extract the vast mineral resources (especially slate) of the area. Unfortunately, for Van Wert, a wealthy landowner donated a large tract of land for the railroad to build a station just to the northwest of town, and Rockmart was born. Because of the location of the train station, Rockmart boomed, and Van Wert stagnated and declined. In 1995, Van Wert lost its charter, but due to its historical significance, it was declared a special historical district, and therefore it cannot be annexed by the City of Rockmart, thereby retaining its unique identity.

properties.name: Wild Horse Creek Park Trailhead
properties.description: Posted by Mountainmaverick    Powder Springs, GAThis trailhead serves as the beginning of the Wild Horse Creek Trail, which follows Wild Horse Creek up to Wild Horse Creek Park on Macedonia Road. This is a beautiful trail which integrates with the extensive Powder Springs sidewalk network and provides easy access to the Silver Comet Trail for the northeast quarter of the city. This trail has some incredible views of wetlands including the mouth of Noses Creek and a two story wooden deck, which provides shade and shelter in addition to an excellent view of one of Powder Springs\' many swamps.

properties.name: William Wigley House, 1864
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickDallas, GADuring the fighting here in Paulding County, General Joseph Johnston set up his headquarters here at William and Fanny Wigley\'s house from May 25 - June 1. Posey Wigley, son of William and Fanny, who was ten years old in 1864, later recalled seeing General Johnston at his widowed mother\'s house. He also said that he remembered that Johnston had them and their belongings removed to safety.

properties.name: Yorkville Community
properties.description: Posted by MountainmaverickRockmart, GAThis community was an important landmark for Major General James McPherson\'s Army of the Tennessee. Currently, Old US 278 AKA Gold Mine Road and GA 101 intersect here. Back in 1864, it was the junction of the Dallas - Van Wert Road and the Van Wert - Union Road. General James McPherson\'s Army of the Tennessee moved out of Resaca to Wooley\'s Bridge on the Etowah River about two miles west of Kingston. While the Army of the Cumberland and the Army of the Ohio moved south-southeast towards Cartersville and Stegall\'s Station (Now known as Emerson), General McPherson\'s Army of the Tennessee moved south-southwest through Euharleyville (now called Euharlee), Stilesboro, present day Taylorsville, present day Aragon, present day Rockmart, and Van Wert. McPherson then drove southeast into Paulding County towards Yorkville. From Yorkville, his army turned east and approached Dallas from the west while the Armies of the Cumberland and Ohio approached Dallas, New Hope, and Pickett\'s Mill from the north.
